column4: Hi.  I'm trying to connect to the internet on my desktop computer.   For some reason, the default network manager is telling me that my devices are "unmanaged".... how do I fix this?
have you tried to set a static ip?
I have in the past.....  do I need to disable that or something?
check your /etc/network/interfaces file - if you see something about your Wireless i'd try and remove it and see what happens
There's stuff there about my wireless, but it doesn't have any information about ip addresses or anything.  Should I remove it anyway?
if you see wireless in that file i think that's why it's "not managed" in network manager - i'd back the file up and try removing the wireless stuff - then reboot and see if NM then picks it up.

AH!  Somewhere in the middle I got internet! I saw the weather in my gnome panel! but now it's gone....   I don't feel like restarting my pc, but I can if I need to.  What's the command to reload the network manager?
Well, never mind.   network Manager still says I'm unmanaged, but I'm connected somehow!
not sure but you could try "sudo /etc/init.d/networking restart"
yes if it's a partition - but not at the same time...
Hahaha.... alright... Ha! Now time to start working on some dual-booting.....
grub lives in the MBR of the drive - so there is no Partition required for it

what Flannel and jrib are saying is so true, but if you want to try different distros it's certainly possible to multi-boot as many linux/bsd/windows os's as you want with grub -- and all the linux's can use a common swap partition - have fun.
Alright.  I'll probably try kde on ubuntu, and maybe I'll try Fedora another day.
Thank you very much.     Man I want an ssd.
actually the ssd in my eee is slower then my desktop SATA HD
Really?  Oh well... All my hardware still has IDE.....   I have older stuff.
